translated: Commentary on the AbhidharmakoÅ›a, Fascicle 4ğŸ”½
Composed by Venerable Sthiramati
One moment, verse:
The five internal ones have ripening and nourishment, sound is not born of ripening,
Eight are without obstruction and outflow, and also have the nature of being born of ripening,
The other three are real and only mental, the moment is only the last three.
The five internal ones are the five elements of the eye.
Among the eighteen elements, how many are seeing and how many are not seeing?
Verse:
The eye and a part of the dharma element are said to be the eight kinds of seeing,
The wisdom that arises together with the five consciousnesses is not seeing because it does not discriminate.
The eye sees the same kind of form, not the consciousness that relies on it,
It is said that it cannot observe form that is obstructed,
The treatise says:
Because the eye is entirely seeing.
A part of the dharma element is the eight kinds of seeing, the rest are all not seeing.
The treatise says:
Now we will briefly explain the definite characteristics of this.
Verse:
The eye is not lower than the body, and form and consciousness are not higher than the eye.
Form is to consciousness in all cases, and the two are to the body in the same way.
As with the eye, so is it with the ear. The next three are all of their own stage.
Body consciousness is of its own or lower stages. Mental consciousness should be understood as indefinite.
Treatise:

translated: The sÅ«tra also speaks of twenty-two faculties, namely the eye faculty, ear faculty, nose faculty, tongue faculty, body faculty, mind faculty, female faculty, male faculty, life faculty, pleasure faculty, pain faculty, joy faculty, sorrow faculty, equanimity faculty, faith faculty, zeal faculty, mindfulness faculty, concentration faculty, wisdom faculty, faculty of knowing the unknown, faculty of knowing, and faculty of having known.
Explanation:
What sÅ«tra is this from?
It is said that there was a brÄhman named JÄtiÅ›Å«ra who came to where the Buddha was, joyfully greeted him, sat to one side, and said to the Buddha:
How many faculties are established to include all faculties?
The Buddha said:
I say that the twenty-two faculties encompass all faculties.
If one refutes this and speaks of other faculties, know that their words are meaningless.
